intro: Zingiber meghalayense, commonly known as the Meghalaya ginger, is a rare and endemic species native to the northeastern region of India. It belongs to the Zingiberaceae family, which includes other economically important plants like ginger and turmeric. The plant is characterized by its ornate, lance-shaped leaves and fragrant, yellowish flowers that bloom in clusters. Its rhizomes, though not as widely cultivated as common ginger, are used in local traditional medicine for their purported therapeutic properties. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a valuable subject for botanical research and conservation efforts.
